case_name: Baban Singh and Dharichhan Kuer v. Jagdish Singh and Parmhans

facts.text: This is a Criminal Appeal No. 74 of 1964 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 74 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 3, 1963 of the Pat

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated October 3, 1963 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Misc. Case No. 366 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 3, 1963 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Misc. Case No. 366 of 1956. Naunit Lal, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appeal by Baban Singh and his wife Dharichhan Kuer under s. 476-B of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: Naunit Lal, for the appellant. The respondent did number appear. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hidayatullah, J. This is an appeal under s. 476-B of the Code of Criminal Procedure by one Baban Singh and his wife Dharichhan Kuer against a judgment and order of the High Court at Patna ordering the Registrar to file a companyplaint against them under s. 199 of the Indian Penal Code for making false affidavits.

facts.text: Patna High Court ordered Registrar to file a complaint against Baban Singh and Dharichhan Kuer under s. 199 IPC for making false affidavits.

anchor.surface_text: ...against a judgment and order of the High Court at Patna ordering the Registrar to file a companyplaint against them under s. 199 of the Indian Penal Code for making false affidavits. The respondents are persons who had moved the High Court under s. 476 of the Code for the prosecution of the appellants in the following circumstances.

facts.text: Jagdish Singh and Parmhans were appellants in F. A. 301 of 1952 in the Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are persons who had moved the High Court under s. 476 of the Code for the prosecution of the appellants in the following circumstances. Jagdish Singh and Parmhans were appellants in F. A. 301 of 1952 in the High Court at Patna.

facts.text: Mst. Dharichhan Kuer was respondent No. 13 in F.A. 301 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: ...in the High Court at Patna. Mst. Dharichhan Kuer was respondent No. 13 in that appeal. During the pendency of the appeal a companypromise was said to have been arrived at between Dharichhan Kuer on the one hand and Jagdish Singh and Parmhans on the other.

facts.text: During pendency of F.A. 301/1952, a compromise was arrived at between Dharichhan Kuer, Jagdish Singh and Parmhans.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal a companypromise was said to have been arrived at between Dharichhan Kuer on the one hand and Jagdish Singh and Parmhans on the other. Dharichhan Kuer and Jagdish Singh swore an affidavit on June 22, 1953 in support of the petition for companypromise which was filed in the High Court.

facts.text: Dharichhan Kuer and Jagdish Singh swore affidavits on June 22, 1953 in support of compromise petition.

anchor.surface_text: Dharichhan Kuer and Jagdish Singh swore an affidavit on June 22, 1953 in support of the petition for companypromise which was filed in the High Court. Baban Singhs brother identified Dharichhan Kuer before the Oath Commissioner and Rs. 4,000 were paid to Dharichhan Kuer under the terms of the companypromise in the Commissioners presence.

facts.text: Baban Singh's brother identified Dharichhan Kuer before the Oath Commissioner and Rs. 4,000 were paid to her in his presence.

anchor.surface_text: Baban Singhs brother identified Dharichhan Kuer before the Oath Commissioner and Rs. 4,000 were paid to Dharichhan Kuer under the terms of the companypromise in the Commissioners presence. Dharichhan Kuer also passed a receipt and her thumb impression was identified by Baban Singhs brother.

facts.text: Dharichhan Kuer passed a receipt with thumb impression identified by Baban Singh's brother.

anchor.surface_text: Dharichhan Kuer also passed a receipt and her thumb impression was identified by Baban Singhs brother. The petition of companypromise was filed in companyrt on July 13, 1953. The same day Baban Singh swore an affidavit  Ex. B  denying the companypromise or that his wife had received Rs. 4,000.

facts.text: Compromise petition filed in High Court on July 13, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The petition of companypromise was filed in companyrt on July 13, 1953. The same day Baban Singh swore an affidavit  Ex. B  denying the companypromise or that his wife had received Rs. 4,000. This affidavit was filed in the High Court on July 31, 1953.

facts.text: Baban Singh swore affidavit Ex. B on July 13, 1953 denying compromise and receipt of Rs. 4,000 by his wife.

anchor.surface_text: The same day Baban Singh swore an affidavit  Ex. B  denying the companypromise or that his wife had received Rs. 4,000. This affidavit was filed in the High Court on July 31, 1953. On September 9, 1953 Dharichhan Kuer also filed an affidavit  Ex. A  in support of her husband.

facts.text: Baban Singh's affidavit Ex. B filed in High Court on July 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: This affidavit was filed in the High Court on July 31, 1953. On September 9, 1953 Dharichhan Kuer also filed an affidavit  Ex. A  in support of her husband. As the companypromise was in dispute the High Court ordered the Registrar to hold an enquiry.

facts.text: Dharichhan Kuer filed affidavit Ex. A on September 9, 1953 in support of her husband.

anchor.surface_text: On September 9, 1953 Dharichhan Kuer also filed an affidavit  Ex. A  in support of her husband. As the companypromise was in dispute the High Court ordered the Registrar to hold an enquiry. Nine witnesses were examined on behalf of Jagdish Singh and Parmhans including the Oath Commissioner.

facts.text: High Court ordered Registrar to hold enquiry into compromise due to dispute.

anchor.surface_text: As the companypromise was in dispute the High Court ordered the Registrar to hold an enquiry. Nine witnesses were examined on behalf of Jagdish Singh and Parmhans including the Oath Commissioner. Dharichhan Kuer and her husband Baban Singh gave evidence on their own behalf.

facts.text: Nine witnesses examined on behalf of Jagdish Singh and Parmhans including Oath Commissioner; Baban Singh and Dharichhan Kuer gave evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Nine witnesses were examined on behalf of Jagdish Singh and Parmhans including the Oath Commissioner. Dharichhan Kuer and her husband Baban Singh gave evidence on their own behalf. The Registrar reported on July 14, 1954 that the companypromise was genuine and that Dharichhan Kuer had, in fact, sworn the affidavit before the Oath Commissioner and had received Rs. 4,000.

facts.text: Registrar reported on July 14, 1954 that compromise was genuine, Dharichhan Kuer swore affidavit before Oath Commissioner and received Rs. 4,000.

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar reported on July 14, 1954 that the companypromise was genuine and that Dharichhan Kuer had, in fact, sworn the affidavit before the Oath Commissioner and had received Rs. 4,000. B. N. Rai and Kanhaiya Singh, JJ. accepted the report by their order dated October 5, 1956.

facts.text: B. N. Rai and Kanhaiya Singh, JJ. accepted Registrar's report on October 5, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: B. N. Rai and Kanhaiya Singh, JJ. accepted the report by their order dated October 5, 1956. One of the terms of the companypromise was that if Dharichhan Kuer resiled from it the amount of Rs. 4,000 would be refunded with companyts Rs. 500.

facts.text: One term of compromise: if Dharichhan Kuer resiled, refund Rs. 4,000 with costs Rs. 500.

anchor.surface_text: One of the terms of the companypromise was that if Dharichhan Kuer resiled from it the amount of Rs. 4,000 would be refunded with companyts Rs. 500. Dharichhan Kuer deposited this amount in companyrt on October 9, 1956. The first appeal was then heard and disposed of.

facts.text: Dharichhan Kuer deposited Rs. 4,500 in court on October 9, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Dharichhan Kuer deposited this amount in companyrt on October 9, 1956. The first appeal was then heard and disposed of. The application under s. 476 out of which this appeal has arisen was filed during the pendency of the first appeal and was taken up for hearing after the appeal was disposed of.

facts.text: F.A. 301/1952 was heard and disposed of after the deposit.

anchor.surface_text: The first appeal was then heard and disposed of. The application under s. 476 out of which this appeal has arisen was filed during the pendency of the first appeal and was taken up for hearing after the appeal was disposed of.

facts.text: Application under s. 476 filed during pendency of first appeal, heard after its disposal.

anchor.surface_text: The application under s. 476 out of which this appeal has arisen was filed during the pendency of the first appeal and was taken up for hearing after the appeal was disposed of. A question arose whether a companyplaint for prosecution of Baban Singh and Dharichhan Kuer for an offence under s. 193, Indian Penal Code companyld be filed in the High Court because Baban Singh and Dharichhan Kuer had deposed number before the companyrt but before the Registrar.

facts.text: Section 479A introduced from January 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Further s. 479A  to which we shall refer presently  was introduced from January 1, 1956 and thus on October 5, 1956, when the High Court accepted the report of the Registrar, it was in force.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside the order for prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal succeeds and is allowed. The order for the prosecution of the appellants is set aside.
This is an appeal under s. 476-B of the Code of Criminal Procedure by one Baban Singh and his wife Dharichhan Kuer against a judgment
and order of the High Court at Patna ordering the Registrar to file a companyplaint against them under s. 199 of the Indian Penal Code for making false affidavits.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are persons who had moved the High Court under s. 476 of the Code for the prosecution of the appellants in the following

concepts.unlisted_description: Prosecution for offences against public justice including false evidence

anchor.surface_text: A question arose whether a companyplaint for prosecution of Baban Singh and Dharichhan Kuer for an offence under s. 193, Indian Penal Code
Further s. 479A  to which we shall refer presently  was introduced from January 1, 1956 and thus on October 5, 1956,

concepts.unlisted_description: Procedure in cases of false evidence

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before the High Court that a prosecution under S. 199 of the Indian Penal Code would be equally covered by s. 479A
The appellants now appeal as of right under s. 476B.

concepts.interpretation: Special procedure mandatory for witnesses giving or fabricating false evidence; bars ss.476-479 by sub-s.(6)

issues.text: whether a complaint for prosecution of Baban Singh and Dharichhan Kuer for an offence under s. 193, Indian Penal Code could be filed in the High Court because Baban Singh and Dharichhan Kuer had deposed not before the court but before the Registrar

anchor.surface_text: A question arose whether a companyplaint for prosecution of Baban Singh and Dharichhan Kuer for an offence under s. 193, Indian Penal Code

issues.text: whether a prosecution under S. 199 of the Indian Penal Code would be equally covered by s. 479A

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before the High Court that a prosecution under S. 199 of the Indian Penal Code would be equally covered by s. 479A

issues.text: whether S. 476 could at all be invoked because of the bar contained in S. 479A sub S. 6

anchor.surface_text: The short question in this case is whether S. 476 could at all be invoked because of the bar contained in S. 479A sub S.

issues.text: whether proceedings under s. 479A could be taken against Baban Singh and his wife

anchor.surface_text: The point to decide, therefore, is whether proceedings under s. 479A could be taken against Baban Singh and his wife,

issues.text: Does the swearing of the false affidavits amount to an offence under s. 199, Indian Penal Code or under either s. 191 or 192, Indian Penal Code

arguments.claim: A prosecution under s. 199 IPC would be equally covered by s. 479A CrPC and since procedure under s. 479A was not followed, application under s. 476 CrPC is barred

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before the High Court that a prosecution under S. 199 of the Indian Penal Code would be equally covered by s. 479A and as the procedure under that section was number followed an application for prosecution under S. 476 was barred.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the judicial proceeding. The first refers to an offence under s. 191/193 and the second to that under s. 192/193 of the Indian Penal Code. In respect

arguments.court_reasoning: Offence falls under ss.191/193 or 192/193 IPC to which s.479A mandatorily applies, barring s.476 by sub-s.(6)

arguments.claim: s. 479A CrPC applies to offence under s. 193 IPC even though evidence recorded before Registrar, not court

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges in the High Court did number take action in respect of the offence of giving false evidence on oath, as defined in s. 191 and punishable under s. 193 of the Indian Penal Code, because they were of the opinion that s. 479-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure would be applicable to that offence even though evidence was recorded by the Registrar.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: er s. 192/193 of the Indian Penal Code. In respect of such offenses- when companymitted by a witness, action under s. 479-A alone can be taken. The ap

arguments.court_reasoning: Appellants were witnesses in the High Court inquiry before Registrar

arguments.claim: Prima facie offence under s. 199 IPC committed in relation to the two affidavits Exs. A and B

anchor.surface_text: The High Court selected for action the offence in relation to the two affidavits holding that prima facie an offence under s. 199, Indian Penal Code was committed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Swearing false affidavits constitutes offence under s.191 or s.192 IPC, not s.199

arguments.claim: False affidavits constitute offence under s. 191 IPC as they are declarations made under oath by person bound to state truth

anchor.surface_text: Section 191 deals with statements and declarations falsely made by a person legally bound by an oath or by an express provision of law to state the truth. ... the offence is constituted by swearing falsely when one is bound by oath to state the truth because an affidavit is a declaration made under an oath.

arguments.claim: False affidavits also constitute offence under s. 192 IPC as fabricating false evidence by making document containing false statement for judicial proceeding

anchor.surface_text: The offence may also fall within. 192. It lays ,down inter alia that a person is said to fabricate false evidence if he makes a document containing a false statement intending that such false statement may appear in evidence in a judicial proceeding...

arguments.claim: s. 199 IPC contention rejected; offence under ss.191/192 IPC, so s.476 proceedings barred by s.479A(6) CrPC as special procedure mandatory for witnesses giving or fabricating false evidence

anchor.surface_text: They were thus prima facie guilty of an offence of giving false evidence or of fabricating false evidence for the purpose of being used in a judicial proceeding. Section 479-A lays down a special procedure which applies to persons who appear as witnesses...

arguments.claim: Appellants were witnesses before High Court in inquiry who intentionally fabricated false evidence, so s.479A procedure must be followed

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were witnesses in the inquiry in the High Court and they had fabricated false evidence. If any prosecution was to be started against them the High Court ought to have followed the procedure under S. 479-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.text: Swearing of false affidavits constitutes an offence under s. 191 IPC as it is giving false evidence on oath
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit is declaration made under oath by person legally bound to state truth, fitting definition in s.191 IPC

holdings.text: Swearing of false affidavits also constitutes fabricating false evidence under s. 192 IPC
holdings.reasoning_summary: False statements in affidavits tendered in High Court intended to cause court to form erroneous opinion on compromise, fitting s.192 definition

holdings.text: Appellants prima facie committed offence of giving or fabricating false evidence under ss. 191/193 or 192/193 IPC

anchor.surface_text: In this way their offence came within the words of ss. 191/192 rather than S. 199 of the Indian Penal Code. They were thus prima facie guilty of an offence of giving false evidence or of fabricating false evidence for the purpose of being used in a judicial proceeding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Offence fits ss.191/192 rather than s.199 as explained by application of statutory language to facts of false affidavits

holdings.text: Section 479A CrPC mandates special procedure for prosecution of witnesses who intentionally give false evidence (s.191/193 IPC) or fabricate false evidence (s.192/193 IPC), barring proceedings under ss.476-479 by sub-s.(6)

anchor.surface_text: Section 479-A lays down a special procedure which applies to persons who appear as witnesses before civil, revenue or criminal ,courts and do one of two things  i  intentionally give false evidence in any stage of the judicial proceeding or  ii  intentionally fabricate false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of the judicial proceeding. The first refers to an offence under s. 191/193 and the second to that under s. 192/193 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text of s.479A specifies applicability to specified offences by witnesses and expressly bars other procedures via sub-s.(6)

holdings.text: Appellants appeared as witnesses before the High Court in its inquiry and intentionally fabricated false evidence

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were witnesses in the inquiry in the High Court and they had fabricated false evidence. If any prosecution was to be started against them the High Court ought to have followed the procedure under S. 479-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: They gave evidence in Registrar's enquiry ordered by High Court regarding disputed compromise, constituting appearance as witnesses in judicial proceeding

holdings.text: High Court ought to have followed s.479A procedure; action under s.476 barred by s.479A(6)

anchor.surface_text: Not having done so, the action under s. 476 of the Code of Criminal Procedure was number open because of sub-s.  6  of s. 479-A and the order under appeal cannot be allowed to stand.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since s.479A applicable to appellants' offences as witnesses, mandatory procedure not followed renders s.476 proceedings invalid per statutory bar

holdings.text: Appeal allowed and order directing prosecution under s.199 IPC set aside

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal succeeds and is allowed. The order for the prosecution of the appellants is set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in proceeding under s.476 for offence actually governed by s.479A

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal succeeds and is allowed. The order for the prosecution of the appellants is set aside.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order directing filing of complaint for prosecution set aside
directions: The order for the prosecution of the appellants is set aside

The holding addresses the issue by explaining that s.479A mandates a special procedure barring other prosecutions like under s.476.

anchor.surface_text: Section 479-A lays down a special procedure which applies to persons who appear as witnesses before civil, revenue or criminal ,courts and do one of two things  i  intentionally give false evidence in any stage of the judicial proceeding or  ii  intentionally fabricate false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of the judicial proceeding. The first refers to an offence under s. 191/193 and the second to that under s. 192/193 of the Indian Penal Code.
In the result the appeal succeeds and is allowed. The order for the prosecution of the appellants is set aside.
